Driver SDK V2 (Entity Model) / Entity Model API Reference / Camera API Reference

Camera API Reference

This section lists the various properties, commands, events, and types that make up the Device Driver Entity Model API for Camera devices.

Camera

cameraBrightness

Enables changing the brightness of the image captured by the device.

Brightness may control any factor that contributes to overall image brightness, including but not limited to iris, shutter speed (the latter two make up exposure compensation), gain, and post processing.

Commands

raise

Fully Qualified Id: cameraBrightness:raise

Raises the image brightness.

May disable the isAutoAdjustEnabled property which may need to be manually re-enabled later by the user.

Parameters
Name Details
action

Whether to pulse this function or perform press and hold

typeRef: crestron:CommandFunction
Example
Copy 
[EntityCommand(Id = "cameraBrightness:raise")]
    public void CameraBrightnessRaise(CommandFunction action)
    {
        // TODO Your code here
    }
lower

Fully Qualified Id: cameraBrightness:lower

Lowers the image brightness.

May disable the isAutoAdjustEnabled property which may need to be manually re-enabled later by the user.

Parameters
Name Details

Whether to pulse this function or perform press and hold

typeRef: crestron:CommandFunction
Example
Copy

    {
        // TODO Your code here
    }
set

Fully Qualified Id: cameraBrightness:set

Directly sets the image brightness.

May disable the isAutoAdjustEnabled property which may need to be manually re-enabled later by the user.

Parameters
Name Details
level

The relative level to set.

If the device does not support this exact level, the level will be rounded to the closest supported value.

relativeRangeProperty: levelRange

typeDef 

    type: number

    range 

        minimum: 0

        maximum: 1

        double level)
    {
        // TODO Your code here
    }

cameraPrivacy

Enables control over the privacy mode of a camera.

Privacy includes behaviors that physically hide any subjects from the video e.g. closing a shutter or tilting the camera backwards.

Commands

enable

Fully Qualified Id: cameraPrivacy:enable

Enables the cameras privacy mode.

cameraTrackingFraming

Enables control over automatic tracking and/or framing features of a camera.

Types

Mode

Fully Qualified Id: cameraTrackingFraming:Mode

Describes a way in which automatic tracking or framing occurs.

Properties
Name Details
name

The name of the tracking or framing mode.

Type: string
supportsIsActive

True if the mode supports "is active" feedback

If false, the value of isActive must be ignored and the driver may omit it entirely. If this property is omitted, it defaults to false, which means that any driver supporting isActive must explicitly also include this property and set it to true. This also means a driver may omit both isActive and supportsIsActive and the application should interpret that as the driver not supporting the isActive flag.

This property will typically not change values.

Type: bool
isActive

Whether this tracking or framing mode is active.

Type: bool
Constructor and Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "cameraTrackingFraming:Mode")]
    public class CameraTrackingFramingMode
    {
        public CameraTrackingFramingMode(
            string name,
            bool supportsIsActive,
            bool isActive
        )
        {
            Name = name;
            SupportsIsActive = supportsIsActive;
            IsActive = isActive;
        }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public string Name { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public bool SupportsIsActive { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public bool IsActive { get; }
    }

Commands

enable

Fully Qualified Id: cameraTrackingFraming:enable

Enables the tracking and/or framing of the device in its entirety.

When enabling after tracking or framing was disabled, the last known active tracking and framing modes must become activated either by the device if supported or by the driver.

When enabling for the first time and setModes hasn't been called, a default tracking or framing mode (either determined by the device or driver) must be activated.

Example
Copy 
[EntityCommand(Id = "cameraTrackingFraming:enable")]
    public void CameraTrackingFramingEnable()
    {
        // TODO Your code here
    }
disable

Fully Qualified Id: cameraTrackingFraming:disable

Disables the tracking and framing behavior of the device in its entirety.

Example
Copy 
[EntityCommand(Id = "cameraTrackingFraming:disable")]
    public void CameraTrackingFramingDisable()
    {
        // TODO Your code here
    }
setModes

Fully Qualified Id: cameraTrackingFraming:setModes

Sets one or more tracking and/or framing modes.

Setting a tracking and/or framing mode must enable the overall tracking and framing of the device if it is disabled.

If a tracking or framing mode is specified with the same active state as the internal state, the specified tracking or framing mode change must be ignored.

Parameters
Name Details
modes

A dictionary keyed by each key of the tracking and/or framing mode in allModes to change having values of each associated new active state.

Modes that are not specified will maintain their current active status unless they are mutually exclusive with another mode, which will then be updated in the driver.

typeDef 

    type: object

    itemType: boolean
Example
Copy 
[EntityCommand(Id = "cameraTrackingFraming:setModes")]
    public void CameraTrackingFramingSetModes(IDictionary<string, bool> modes)
    {
        // TODO Your code here
    }

Properties

isEnabled

Fully Qualified Id: cameraTrackingFraming:isEnabled

Whether the automatic tracking and framing feature is enabled.

If the device allows enabling the automatic tracking and framing while having no active tracking or framing modes, then this property must be reported as false if no modes are active regardless of the feature status.

typeDef 

    type: boolean

Example
Copy 
[EntityProperty(Id = "cameraTrackingFraming:isEnabled")]
    public bool CameraTrackingFramingIsEnabled { get; set; }
    
    private void TriggerCameraTrackingFramingIsEnabledChangedEvent()
    {
        NotifyPropertyChanged("cameraTrackingFraming:isEnabled", new DriverEntityValue(CameraTrackingFramingIsEnabled));
    }
allModes

Fully Qualified Id: cameraTrackingFraming:allModes

typeDef 

    type: object

    itemTypeRef: Mode

Example
Copy

    }

Common

commandFunction

Defines an enumeration to be used for press and hold functionality across many driver capabilities

Types

crestron:CommandFunction

Fully Qualified Id: crestron:CommandFunction

Describes the operation of a command which may be issued once or may be repeated for some duration.

The most common use case for this is remote control button emulation. A single tap would send a pulse, but pressing and holding the button would send high until the button is released and then low at the end.

Sending high and then low immediately is not equivalent to sending pulse in all cases. Applications should make their own determination on when to treat a press as a pulse versus high/low.

Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "crestron:CommandFunction")]
    public enum CommandFunction
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// Indicates a single, momentary operation.
        /// If <see cref="High"/> was previously used, this stops that operation and begins the
        /// new single pulse operation.
        /// </summary>
        Pulse,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Indicates the beginning of an ongoing operation.
        /// If <see cref="High"/> was previously used, this will have no effect since it is
        /// already started.
        /// Callers MUST ensure they follow up with <see cref="Low"/> eventually to avoid a
        /// runaway condition where the operation goes on forever.
        /// </summary>
        High,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Indicates the end of an ongoing operation.
        /// If <see cref="High"/> was not previously used, this will have no effect since it is
        /// already stopped.
        /// </summary>
        Low,
    }

icon

Defines icon types

Types

crestron:Icon

Fully Qualified Id: crestron:Icon

Describes an icon and provides the necessary information to retrieve it

Note: This type is mostly a placeholder at the time of writing. These descriptions will be updated once applications support this and a list of supported uri schemes and mime types is available.

Properties
Name Details
uri

The uri at which the icon image can be retrieved

This typically will start with http:// or file://. Do NOT use base64 content here.

Type: string
type

The Mime Type of the image

For Crestron-defined icons, use "application/x-crestron-icon-id". This description will be updated with more information once applications support this.

Type: string
categories

Category tags that apply to this icon

May be null or empty if none are applicable.

Type: ICollection<IconCategory>
Constructor and Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "crestron:Icon")]
    public class Icon
    {
        public Icon(
            string uri,
            string type,
            ICollection<IconCategory> categories
        )
        {
            Uri = uri;
            Type = type;
            Categories = categories;
        }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public string Uri { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public string Type { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public ICollection<IconCategory> Categories { get; }
    }
crestron:IconCategory

Fully Qualified Id: crestron:IconCategory

Describes categories that an icon may be tagged with

Developers should expect this list to be expanded over time.

Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "crestron:IconCategory")]
    public enum IconCategory
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// Indicates that the icon is designed for a light UI theme
        /// </summary>
        Light,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Indicates that the icon is designed for a dark UI theme
        /// </summary>
        Dark,
    }

levelTransition

Defines a type used for levels that transition over a period of time

Types

crestron:LevelTransition

Fully Qualified Id: crestron:LevelTransition

Describes a transition from one value to another

When paired with a property indicating the present level, that property will typically report a stale value during a transition. The property with this type will typically be null when a transition is not active. However, refer to the documentation of the specific properties for final clarification.

Properties
Name Details
target

The target that the level will be at the end of the transition period

Note that if the transition is interrupted, the actual level is not guaranteed to reach this value.

Type: double
duration

The total duration of the transition from start to target

If omitted or zero, the duration is unknown. This duration should not be updated during the transition since it represents the total transition time, not remaining time.

If the application needs to animate the transition, it must listen for property changes before this property updates in order to be notified and know when the transition starts.

Type: long
start

The starting value being transitioned from, if known

May be omitted if not known. Note that a driver that does report the starting value once may still later report a transition without a start value.

Type: double?
Constructor and Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "crestron:LevelTransition")]
    public class LevelTransition
    {
        public LevelTransition(
            double target,
            long duration,
            double? start
        )
        {
            Target = target;
            Duration = duration;
            Start = start;
        }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public double Target { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public long Duration { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public double? Start { get; }
    }

uxCategory

Defines the crestron:DeviceUxCategory enumeration

Types

crestron:DeviceUxCategory

Fully Qualified Id: crestron:DeviceUxCategory

The User Experience category for a device

This describes the type of device that it is. It should ONLY be used for categorization purposes for selecting an icon or helping organize the device into a list. It should NOT be used to determine how to use the device.

In practice, devices can fit into multiple of these categories. The driver developer may have to choose what they consider the closest, or use "other" if no other categories apply. Applications should inspect the definition of the device instance to determine its capabilities and assume nothing about the device based on this string.

Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "crestron:DeviceUxCategory")]
    public enum DeviceUxCategory
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// The device did not fit into any of the predefined categories
        /// </summary>
        Other,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily an audio amplifier
        /// </summary>
        Amplifier,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily an appliance, such as a stove, oven, coffee maker,
        /// microwave, dishwasher, or similar device.
        /// </summary>
        Appliance,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device represents an area, rolling up any states and control for the devices and
        /// rooms in the area to an area-level API.
        /// An area is defined as a space (physical or virtual) that may be stateful and
        /// controllable as a whole, composed of devices, rooms, and nested areas (which may or
        /// may not be listed) that belong to that area. A device, room, or area may only be
        /// directly contained by one parent area. A hierarchy of areas, rooms, and devices is
        /// like a tree structure where each node has a single parent.
        /// </summary>
        Area,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily an audio mixer
        /// </summary>
        AudioMixer,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily an audio processor / pre-amp
        /// </summary>
        AudioProcessor,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily an Audio/Video Receiver (AVR)
        /// </summary>
        AvReceiver,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily an Audio/Video Switcher
        /// </summary>
        AvSwitcher,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily an Audio Switcher
        /// </summary>
        AudioSwitcher,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a Bluray player
        /// </summary>
        BlurayPlayer,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a Cable Box (as in the cable signal receiver for a TV, not a
        /// storage crate for wires)
        /// </summary>
        CableBox,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a camera, usually with PTZ (pan, tilt, zoom) capabilities
        /// </summary>
        Camera,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a video display device
        /// </summary>
        Display,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a door, such as an interior or exterior door (excluding
        /// garage doors which have their own category).
        /// </summary>
        Door,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a fan
        /// </summary>
        Fan,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a fireplace
        /// </summary>
        Fireplace,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a video game console, such as an XBOX, PlayStation, or
        /// Nintendo.
        /// </summary>
        GameConsole,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a garage door
        /// </summary>
        GarageDoor,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a gate
        /// </summary>
        Gate,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device represents a group of entities, rolling up any states and control for
        /// members of the group to a group-level API.
        /// Groups may overlap, contain other groups, and contain devices from various rooms and
        /// areas.
        /// </summary>
        Group,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily an HVAC device, like a thermostat, heating / air
        /// conditioning system, humidifier, dehumidifier, or similar device.
        /// </summary>
        Hvac,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily an intercom system
        /// </summary>
        Intercom,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily an irrigation system, such as a lawn sprinkler system or
        /// garden irrigation system
        /// </summary>
        IrrigationSystem,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a lighting device
        /// </summary>
        Light,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a lock, such as a door lock or other electronic lock
        /// </summary>
        Lock,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a network router device
        /// </summary>
        NetworkRouter,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a network (ethernet) switch
        /// </summary>
        NetworkSwitch,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a smart power outlet / smart plug
        /// </summary>
        Outlet,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a "platform" for other devices, like a gateway to another
        /// ecosystem of devices
        /// </summary>
        Platform,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is a pool, typically contained in and controlled by a pool controller
        /// device. This device is the representation of the pool itself.
        /// </summary>
        Pool,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is a controller for a pool system, typically containing a pool and/or spa
        /// device, as well as other devices
        /// </summary>
        PoolController,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a power controller / power distribution unit (PDU)
        /// </summary>
        PowerController,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a document printer
        /// </summary>
        Printer,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a video projector device
        /// </summary>
        Projector,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a lift for a video projector
        /// </summary>
        ProjectorLift,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a projector screen
        /// </summary>
        ProjectorScreen,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device represents a room, rolling up any states and control for the devices in
        /// the room to a room-level API.
        /// A room is defined as a space (physical or virtual) that may be stateful and
        /// controllable as a whole, composed of devices (which may or may not be listed by the
        /// room) that belong to that room. A device may only be in one room, and a room may not
        /// contain other rooms.
        /// </summary>
        Room,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a document scanner
        /// </summary>
        Scanner,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a security system
        /// </summary>
        SecuritySystem,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a sensor device, such as a door sensor, occupancy sensor,
        /// light sensor, etc.
        /// </summary>
        Sensor,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a window shade, curtain, drapes, etc.
        /// </summary>
        Shade,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is a spa/hot tub, typically contained in and controlled by a pool
        /// controller device. This device is the representation of the spa itself.
        /// </summary>
        Spa,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a speaker
        /// </summary>
        Speaker,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a vacuum cleaner, typically an automatic robotic vacuum, or
        /// a pool vacuum
        /// </summary>
        Vacuum,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a vehicle
        /// </summary>
        Vehicle,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is primarily a Codec device for video conferencing
        /// </summary>
        VideoConferenceCodec,

        /// </summary>

    }

Identification

deviceComponentLabel

Capability to be implemented by a device or device component which is labeled

This label is typically affixed onto the device itself. The label must never change as this is intended to represent the physical marking on the device. For labels that may change dynamically, consider if the deviceName capability applies.

This capability is primarily implemented by sub-devices which represent components of the main device.

For example, a power controller may have multiple banks, labeled something like "Bank 2" or "Aux" on the power controller chassis. It may also support a software-defined "name" for the bank that may be changed via the device user interface. This capability would be used to report that "Bank 2" or "Aux" label that is physically attached to the device (not the software-defined "name").

Properties

text

Fully Qualified Id: deviceComponentLabel:text

The physical label string associated with this device component

typeDef 

    type: string

Example
Copy

    private void TriggerDeviceComponentLabelTextChangedEvent()
    {
        NotifyPropertyChanged("deviceComponentLabel:text", new DriverEntityValue(DeviceComponentLabelText));
    }

deviceIdentification

Capability to be implemented by a device or device component which supports identifying itself by blinking a light, making a sound, displaying a message, etc.

Commands

startIdentifying

Fully Qualified Id: deviceIdentification:startIdentifying

Starts identifying the device by blinking a light, making a sound, displaying a message, or some other similar means

This identification may continue until stopIdentifying is executed, or it may end on its own after some amount of time. If identification interferes with device operation and other device APIs are called, the driver should abort identification and prioritize the other operation if possible.

systemComponentVersions

Fully Qualified Id: deviceInformation:systemComponentVersions

Collection of versions for the various system components

The keys of this collection must be user-friendly identifiers for what version this is. They typically match strings displayed on the device's interface and/or manual. firmwareVersion is used for the device's "primary" firmware version. That property should be used when there is an obvious corresponding value on the device. This property must not include the version from firmwareVersion as that may cause applications to report the version twice. Applications should not assume versions will not be added or removed, even at runtime. A device update may cause it to add, remove, or rename component versions.

typeDef 

    type: object

    itemType: string

Example
Copy 
[EntityProperty(Id = "deviceInformation:systemComponentVersions")]
    public IDictionary<string, string> DeviceInformationSystemComponentVersions { get; set; }
    
    private void TriggerDeviceInformationSystemComponentVersionsChangedEvent()
    {
        NotifyPropertyChanged("deviceInformation:systemComponentVersions", CreateValueForEntries(DeviceInformationSystemComponentVersions));
    }
additionalProperties

Fully Qualified Id: deviceInformation:additionalProperties

An array of names of properties that provide additional information about the device.

These properties are typically driver-defined and are specific to the driver or device, not ones defined in other capabilities. They are intended to allow a device to specify more information about itself than is described by the specific properties existent in this capability.

Note that these properties are typically for informational purposes only. They are intended to be shown on the user interface for the device. They should not be used to determine any type of functionality unless explicitly defined for other purposes.

typeDef 

    type: array

    itemType: string

        NotifyPropertyChanged("deviceInformation:additionalProperties", CreateValueForObjects(DeviceInformationAdditionalProperties));
    }

deviceName

Capability to be implemented by a device or device component which supports a configurable name

This capability is reserved for devices which report their own user-configurable name, and potentially the ability to set that name via the API.

This capability should not be "faked" where the driver emulates this feature.

This "name" is for describing and identifying the device in some user interface. Sometimes the device supports configuring its host name on the network, but that is not the intent of this interface.

This is NOT the label associated with a device component. For that, see the deviceComponentLabel capability.

For example, a power controller may have multiple banks, labeled something like "Bank 2" or "Aux" on the power controller chassis. It may also support a software-defined "name" for the bank that may be changed via the device user interface. This capability would be used to report that software-defined name, not the "Bank 2" or "Aux" label.

trigger

Fully Qualified Id: imageFocus:trigger

Manually starts the auto focus mechanism.

There may be no effect if the device has already determined to be in focus or if auto focus is disabled on the device.

Trigger differs from isAutoAdjustEnabled in that trigger activates the auto focusing mechanism of the device akin to holding down the shutter button on a digital camera instead of being determined by the device.

Using this command may disable isAutoAdjustEnabled since it may disrupt the auto adjusting behavior of the device.

imageZoom

Enables control over the zoom of an image.

Zoom entails scaling image frames whether that be in consumption like a camera or in production like a projector.

Types

ZoomMode

Fully Qualified Id: imageZoom:ZoomMode

Describes zooming behaviors in order to perform zoom operations on the device. May control behavior natively on the device or process data driver-side and control the device correspondingly.

Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "imageZoom:ZoomMode")]
    public enum ImageZoomZoomMode
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// Composite zoom mode is when a device-determined amount of optical and digital zoom
        /// are performed.
        /// </summary>
        Composite,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Prefer Optical mode is when digital zoom is applied only once optical zoom is maxed
        /// out.
        /// </summary>
        PreferOptical,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Prefer Digital mode is when optical zoom is applied only once digital zoom is maxed
        /// out.
        /// </summary>
        PreferDigital,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Only Optical mode will only use optical zoom even if digital zoom is available.
        /// </summary>
        OnlyOptical,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Only Digital mode will only use digital zoom even if optical zoom is available.
        /// </summary>
        OnlyDigital,
    }

Media

mediaContentContext

Provides hints to the application as to how a media source or destination (or input or output, although these are less common) is intended to be used by its manufacturer.

DO NOT USE THIS TO DETERMINE "DEVICE TYPE"!

This ONLY provides hints for setting up reasonable default configurations. A device may still span the lines and qualify as multiple devices. Another device might not implement these at all but be perfectly suitable to use. ALWAYS use the capabilities of the device to determine what it supports and what use cases it qualifies in your system. ONLY use this to provide automatic default behavior that is already manually configurable by the user if this capability did not exist.

For example, an application that handles a conference room should allow for any audio source to be treated as a room microphone since there are a number of ways a microphone signal could be wired into the system. However, if the user adds a dedicated microphone device to the system, the application may desire to add that as a room microphone by default (even though it is still configurable beyond that) as a convenience.

Similarly, if a room contains both a display with integrated speakers and an audio amplifier, the application may wish to default to using the display for video and the amplifier for audio (again, only as a default setup for convenience and not as an enforced rule).

Types

Suitability

Fully Qualified Id: mediaContentContext:Suitability

Describes tiers of suitability for a given use case

A value of null (or equivalent default value in the programming environment) or unimplemented property is equivalent to a suitability of "unknown"

Levels are thoroughly defined so that an application may compare them and have less of a chance of encountering a future-defined level and not knowing where to order it. In most cases, this level of granularity is not needed. Devices should use the preferred values as indicated in the description unless they have a very specific necessary reason to use a reserved one.

Note that an application may not look at these levels at all, or it may not care to distinguish between all of these levels. They are provided only as additional information the application could choose to use to enhance the user experience.

Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "mediaContentContext:Suitability")]
    public enum MediaContentContextSuitability
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// The content is specifically unsuitable for the context.
        /// This is a RESERVED value. Do not use this in a driver without approval from
        /// Crestron.
        /// This value is intended to hint to the application that the content probably should
        /// not even be an option for the context.
        /// Most of the time, such content would not even be listed on the device (like if a
        /// speaker was such low quality that it was not useful as a media device). This value
        /// is reserved in case the application needs to prevent a device from being used in
        /// certain contexts for business logic or legal reasons, such as licensing terms
        /// restricting the uses of a content stream.
        /// Note that this level is specifically NOT designed to indicate that a "camera" is
        /// video-only and does not provide audio. That class of information is contained within
        /// the <see cref="IMediaDevice.Nodes"/> and the associated <see
        /// cref="ContentAttribute"/>s. This suitability is reserved for when the media signal
        /// and connection attributes all look valid, but there is a specific reason to prevent
        /// it from being used in the given context.
        /// </summary>
        Unsuitable,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The content is unlikely to be suitable
        /// This is a RESERVED value. Do not use this in a driver without approval from
        /// Crestron.
        /// The content is less suitable than any "unknown" sources but is possible there is a
        /// corner case where it makes sense.
        /// For example, a digital stethoscope which can stream audio might technically be a
        /// microphone, but in a list of possible microphones to assign for conferencing
        /// purposes, it might be the last option or buried under a "more" menu.
        /// This level is reserved for now since we do not anticipate needing that level of
        /// detail and filtering. Still, it is defined so that if we need it in the future,
        /// applications can know where it lines up.
        /// </summary>
        Unlikely,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The suitability of the content is unknown
        /// This is a PREFERRED value. This should be used in drivers where appropriate. When
        /// the device does not provide a suitability, this is the equivalent default level.
        /// Most content falls into this category. Devices which mix, switch, or stream media do
        /// not usually know what the context of the content is.
        /// This level is more suitable than the "unlikely" level.
        /// </summary>
        Unknown,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// One of the device's secondary functions is suitable for the context
        /// This is a PREFERRED value. This should be used in drivers where appropriate.
        /// A prime example of this is the set of speakers included in a TV. They can and will
        /// be used for room audio for media. However, another device such as a surround sound
        /// system whose primary function is media audio would be more suitable, since that is
        /// the entire reason to have such a device in the system.
        /// </summary>
        Secondary,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device's primary function is suitable for the context
        /// This is a PREFERRED value. This should be used in drivers where appropriate.
        /// This value is used when the device matches the context, like a speaker being used to
        /// play audio or a webcam being used for video conferencing.
        /// </summary>
        Primary,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The device is the most suitable device for this context
        /// This is a RESERVED value. Do not use this in a driver without approval from
        /// Crestron. Crestron developers should not use this level without approval from a
        /// relevant software architect and specific business requirement that justifies it.
        /// This is the highest level of suitability and is reserved for native integrations
        /// where the product is specifically designed for the use case and there is an
        /// application business logic reason why it must be prioritized above the other levels.
        /// It is used sparingly since there is no higher level
        /// </summary>
        Priority,
    }

mediaDevice

Capability to be implemented by a device for it to participate in media-related functionality.

Types

Node

Fully Qualified Id: mediaDevice:Node

Describes a media source or destination for routing, mixing, and other media-related functionality

These can represent inputs or outputs from connectors, media services that serve content, internal sources like mixer outputs, internal destinations like mixer inputs, or even external destinations such as a stream to an external service.

Physical sources (microphones, cameras) and physical destinations (speakers, headphones, displays) will also be listed here. These may or may not have associated connectors. For example, an AVR may have an amplifier as well as audio out and HDMI A/V out all on one destination. Or, it might just be an amplifier, and therefore not have any defined connectors as speakers are considered part of that device from the perspective of this API.

If the application needs to determine more context about the node, it may check if the "entity" property is populated and if that entity implements the mediaContentContext capability which can provide more detailed information.

Properties
Name Details
entity

The ID of an entity which represents the node and provides capabilities for additional control and information, if applicable

May be null if no additional capabilites are needed for this node

In some cases where the device is synonymous with the node, the entity may be the same as the containing mediaDevice. Additionally, if multiple nodes share the same controls and attributes, it is possible the entity will be shared as well. The only thing this property indicates is that the associated entity's control and information apply to and represent this node.

Type: IDriverEntity
name

Name of this node intended to be shown to a user when they are browsing a list of media nodes

Type: string
contentAttributes

Indicates the type(s) of media this supports along with other additional information about the qualities of that media

This is not intended to change dynamically when content is routed or connected. This merely lists out the capabilities of this node and indicates what could be routed.

Note that the attributes for audio and video are independent. Most video content will also support audio, and in those cases both attributes must be present. If only video is listed, the content is picture-only with no audio.

Type: ICollection<MediaDeviceContentAttribute>
icons

Set of icons that represent the media source or destination

Null if none are available

Type: ICollection<Icon>
Constructor and Definition

AvailableRoute

Fully Qualified Id: mediaDevice:AvailableRoute

For each Node that can have media routed to it, this describes the nodes which can be routed and whether or not those routes can be cleared.

The mediaDevice:nodes dictionary will contain a related Node that has the base information about the node. This object adds the additional routing information for the ones that participate in routing.

Properties
Name Details
audioSources

List of nodes from which audio can be routed to this node

This list may change when the list of available dynamic sources changes, but is not intended to change based on things like signal or connector presence. This is the list of what is possible to route, not what should be routed right now.

If the list is null or empty, there are no audio sources that can be routed to this node.

If there are no audio or video sources, the node itself is purely a "source" for media.

Type: ICollection<string>
videoSources

List of nodes from which video can be routed to this node

This list may change when the list of available dynamic sources changes, but is not intended to change based on things like signal or connector presence. This is the list of what is possible to route, not what should be routed right now.

If the list is null or empty, there are no video sources that can be routed to this node.

If there are no audio or video sources, the node itself is purely a "source" for media.

Type: ICollection<string>
permanentlyActive

Indicates that the node is permanently active and routes to it cannot be cleared

This only applies to nodes which have audio and/or video sources.

When paired with only a single supported input, a permanent route is created since the route cannot be cleared and there is no choice as to what content is routed.

Note that while the route may be permanently active, the signal may be blank if the source is missing or if the source/destination is powered off via devicePower.

Type: bool
subContainerId

The ID (key in mediaDevice:sources or mediaDevice:destinations) of a NodeSubContainer that contains this media routing node

Null if this node is not associated with any subcontainer. A subcontainer often represents a physical grouping of nodes, such as a "player" or "channel" to which a set of nodes belong.

Type: string

NodeSubContainer

Fully Qualified Id: mediaDevice:NodeSubContainer

A subcontainer is a group of media nodes that provides additional information about the contained nodes, such as a name for the group.

In addition to providing that information, the subcontainer also indicates to the application that only one of these nodes may be routed at a time.

This may be null if the device does not provide a name for its subcontainers.

Type: string

Output ID assigned to at least one of the nodes belonging to this subcontainer

More specifically, sometimes 3rd party applications can be used to cast audio or video to a particular room/zone (i.e. output ID). The target room/zone will use the casted node from the corresponding "player/channel" (i.e. subcontainer) of the device.

This does not mean some nodes from this subcontainer cannot be routed elsewhere. The device may still allow routing of non-casted nodes to other outputs.

The output ID refers to a mediaDevice:Node defined in the mediaDevice:nodes property.

This output ID will not change once the device is "ready" (or if "ready" is not applicable, then "online").

Connector

Fully Qualified Id: mediaDevice:Connector

Defines a (physical or logical) connector on a device that can be used to configure connections in a System containing media functionality.

Physical connectors are ports on the device that where a cable can be plugged in. Logical connectors may be internal to the device or may be network connections (such as streaming audio or video to another device, but not including internet streaming services which are not connectors).

The type property defines the connector type. See those types for more details.

Properties
Name Details
name

Friendly name for the connector (typically the label next to the physical connector on the device);

For logical connectors, this should appropriately identify the content type being provided.

Type: string
node

The ID of the node (source, destination, or channel) associated with this connector

A connector must always be associated with a node.

Type: string
group

Optional group ID that is shared among logical connectors which connect as a group

For example, the audio return channel (ARC) for an HDMI connector is a connector, but it would share the same group ID so that the application can associate them.

Will be null if the connector is not part of a group.

Type: string
contentAttributes

If populated, indicates the type(s) of media this supports along with other additional information about the qualities of that media

Since connectors are always associated with a node, drivers are allowed to leave this list null or empty to indicate that it supports whatever the node does. This prevents redundant (and possibly invalid) information. Note that nodes are still required to list their content attributes. If a connector has an attribute that the node does not, the node does not inherit the attribute.

This list exists for cases where certain connectors for a node support a subset of the content attributes.

This is not intended to change dynamically when content is routed or connected. This merely lists out the capabilities of this node and indicates what could be routed.

Note that the attributes for audio and video are independent. Most video content will also support audio, and in those cases both attributes must be present. If only video is listed, the content is picture-only with no audio.

Type: ICollection<MediaDeviceContentAttribute>
slotLabel

Whenever two connectors are related, they will share the same slot label, which is the user-facing label matching what is printed on the device.

Connectors which do not have a slot label may omit this property or use null.

This label must be unique among the slots on the device.

For example, Crestron Digital Media cards will often have multiple inputs on the same card. They are naturally related and must be displayed to the user as such.

This field should generally not be longer than a single character. If a longer string is provided make sure to test at runtime that the string fits in the UI.

Type: string
type

Defines the type of this connector

For physical connectors, this is the type of cable that can be plugged in. For logical connectors, this will identify the type of logical connection that can be made.

Based on the quality of this connector type, decisions can be made by the media components in the System as to which is the best connection route to use in a media switching scenario.

Based on this type, the compatibilityIds property may need to be used.

Type: MediaDeviceConnectorType
mutuallyExclusiveConnectors

Set of connector IDs with which this connector is mutually exclusive, where plugging into one disables the other.

This may be null or omitted if there are no mutually exclusive connectors.

Type: ICollection<string>
compatibilityIds

Specifies the connector compatibility (in addition to the type)

Logical connector types will require having this property filled in to be connected and to have media properly routed.

The pipe "|" character is reserved and should not be used in any compatibility ID item. Using the pipe "|" character in a compatibility ID may result in routing errors.

Each compatibility ID in the set indicates that it can only connect to other connectors of the same type and with one of the same IDs. Typically, the compatibility ID would be fall under 2 categories: standard and proprietary protocols.

For example, a standard audio protocol is "AES67". Two device drivers from two different manufacturers could include this compatibility ID and then be compatible with each other within the hosting application/program.

For another example, a streaming device in a proprietary, closed ecosystem will only allow connections within its ecosystem. So each streaming device would define an output connector of type "stream" with one or more compatibility IDs set to any arbitrary string, as long as they match across all the streaming devices in that ecosystem, the hosting application/program would recognize them as compatible.

For proprietary compatibility IDs, it is recommended that they include the manufacturer's name to guarantee uniqueness across different device implementations (to avoid allowing connections to devices from a different manufacturer with an identically specified compatibility ID).

This property is named generically to allow associations between any similar future connector types or even physical connectors (if there is any reason to associate them beyond using their type).

This may be null or omitted if not applicable.

Type: ICollection<string>
Constructor and Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "mediaDevice:Connector")]
    public class MediaDeviceConnector
    {
        public MediaDeviceConnector(
            string name,
            string node,
            string group,
            ICollection<MediaDeviceContentAttribute> contentAttributes,
            string slotLabel,
            MediaDeviceConnectorType type,
            ICollection<string> mutuallyExclusiveConnectors,
            ICollection<string> compatibilityIds
        )
        {
            Name = name;

            Group = group;
            ContentAttributes = contentAttributes;
            SlotLabel = slotLabel;
            Type = type;
            MutuallyExclusiveConnectors = mutuallyExclusiveConnectors;
            CompatibilityIds = compatibilityIds;
        }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public string Name { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public string Node { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public string Group { get; }

        public ICollection<MediaDeviceContentAttribute> ContentAttributes { get; }

        public string SlotLabel { get; }

    }
ContentAttribute

Fully Qualified Id: mediaDevice:ContentAttribute

Enumerates the types of media and the associated qualities of the media

This list will expand in the future as more attributes are required. For example, we may need to add HDCP capability for sources.

All entries must be additive and do not replace or imply another attribute. For example, a new "reallyFancyAudio" attribute might be added, but "audio" should always also be used with it since an application might not be checking for "reallyFancyAudio" and does not know to assume that it also would have implied "audio".

Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "mediaDevice:ContentAttribute")]
    public enum MediaDeviceContentAttribute
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// The media content can include video
        /// Note that this only indicates the picture side of the video. The associated audio is
        /// a separate attribute.
        /// </summary>
        Video,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The media content can include audio
        /// This is also used to represent the audio portion of audio-video content
        /// </summary>
        Audio,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The media audio content supports a stereo signal
        /// This attribute is specified in addition to "audio". If this is present, the node
        /// must also specify that it supports "audio".
        /// </summary>
        StereoAudio,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The media audio content supports a multichannel signal
        /// Here, multichannel typically means some form of surround sound.
        /// This attribute is specified in addition to "audio" and "stereoAudio". If this is
        /// present, the node must also specify that it supports "audio" and "stereoAudio".
        /// </summary>
        MultichannelAudio,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The media audio content supports downmixing a multichannel signal into a stereo
        /// signal (or mono, if "stereoAudio" is not supported)
        /// Here, multichannel typically means some form of surround sound.
        /// This attribute is specified in addition to "audio". If this is present, the node
        /// must also specify that it supports "audio".
        /// If "multichannelAudio" is not supported, this indicates that the node cannot pass
        /// the multichannel signal through and always downmixes.
        /// If "stereoAudio" is not supported, this indicates that the downmixing is into the
        /// supported mono signal.
        /// </summary>
        MultichannelAudioDownmix,
    }
ConnectorType

Fully Qualified Id: mediaDevice:ConnectorType

Describes the physical or logical connection type for the route

Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "mediaDevice:ConnectorType")]
    public enum MediaDeviceConnectorType
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// Custom connector type that carries audio and video (usually something proprietary to
        /// a particular manufacturer)
        /// Connectors of this type must specify at least one ID in the list of compatibility
        /// IDs in order to be connectable to another connector of the same type.
        /// For proprietary connectors types, it is recommended that the compatibility ID(s)
        /// specified include the manufacturer's name to guarantee uniqueness across different
        /// device implementations (to avoid allowing connections to devices from a different
        /// manufacturer with an identically specified compatibility ID).
        /// </summary>
        Custom,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Analog audio, such as RCA connectors or 3.5mm audio jacks
        /// </summary>
        AnalogAudio,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Digital audio (SPDIF) over a coax audio cable
        /// </summary>
        CoaxAudio,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Digital audio (SPDIF) over an optical audio cable (a.k.a TOSLink)
        /// </summary>
        OpticalAudio,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Connector type that takes a composite video cable
        /// </summary>
        CompositeVideo,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Connector type that takes a VGA cable
        /// </summary>
        Vga,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Connector type that takes a RGBHV cable
        /// </summary>
        Rgbhv,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Connector type that takes a DVI cable
        /// </summary>
        Dvi,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Connector type that takes an HDMI cable
        /// </summary>
        Hdmi,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Allows media streaming connections
        /// Nodes with this type of connector must implement <see cref="MediaStreamDecoder"/>
        /// and/or <see cref="MediaStreamEncoder"/> to function properly.
        /// This is a "logical" connector type, so connectors of this type must specify at least
        /// one ID in the list of compatibility IDs in order to be routable to another connector
        /// of the same type.
        /// </summary>
        Stream,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Expander connectors plug into another device and essentially transpose all the
        /// connected inputs of the source device onto the target device.
        /// The expander device's <see cref="IMediaDevice.Route"/> command will be executed with
        /// the same connector IDs as the device from which it is being expanded.
        /// Connectors of this type must specify at least one ID in the list of compatibility
        /// IDs in order to be connectable to another connector of the same type.
        /// </summary>
        Expander,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Catch-all connector type for audio/video, typically defined on an uncontrolled
        /// audio/video source or one which is configurable to use a number of different
        /// connector types
        /// This special type of connector can connect to any other connector that supports
        /// audio and/or video (as appropriate for this connector's audio/video support).
        /// </summary>
        Generic,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Connector type that takes a SDI cable
        /// </summary>
        Sdi,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Connector type that takes a DisplayPort cable
        /// </summary>
        DisplayPort,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Connector type that takes a USB cable
        /// Note that this USB connector is intended for passing an audio and/or video signal
        /// through, not to load preset media out of memory. Playback of media from a USB memory
        /// device is modeled as a media routing node.
        /// </summary>
        Usb,
    }
ActiveRoute

Fully Qualified Id: mediaDevice:ActiveRoute

Indicates which routing node(s) are the active source(s) of audio and/or video for a given node.

This data structure is found in the activeRoutes dictionary, and the dictionary key indicates the destination node that the audio and/or video nodes listed here are routed to. The routing is not necessarily mutually exclusive, so other entries in that dictionary for other nodes may also have the same audio and/or video nodes routed.

Properties
Name Details
audio

The key of the input or media source that audio is being routed from, or null if none is being routed

This can be the same as or different than the video source. It is also valid for only one of the two to be non-null, indicating that only audio or only video is routed.

Note that the entire parent Route object may be null or omitted if no media is routed to this output.

Type: string
video

The key of the input or media source that video is being routed from, or null if none is being routed

This can be the same as or different than the audio source. It is also valid for only one of the two to be non-null, indicating that only audio or only video is routed.

Note that the entire parent Route object may be null or omitted if no media is routed to this output.

Type: string
Constructor and Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "mediaDevice:ActiveRoute")]
    public class MediaDeviceActiveRoute
    {
        public MediaDeviceActiveRoute(
            string audio,
            string video
        )
        {
            Audio = audio;
            Video = video;
        }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public string Audio { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public string Video { get; }
    }

Commands

route

Fully Qualified Id: mediaDevice:route

Routes media from the specified inputs and/or sources to the specified outputs, or clears the route when the input is null (if the output supports being cleared).

If the device supports feedback, the activeRoutes property will update when the route is completed.

Upon configuration or initialization of the System, the availableRoutes property should be used to determine which inputs can be routed to which outputs, and where audio and video are valid to include in those routes.

If the device implements devicePower, the application must ensure that it powers on the device before attempting to route anything. When the input, source, or output has an associated entity for control, the application must also ensure they are powered on before attempting to route them.

For devices that do not support routing video separately than audio, when an audio-video-capable connector is passed into this command, audio and video will both be routed. Routes are applied in the order they are provided to ensure consistent behavior.

All media devices must contain at least one output. For example, even televisions, which technically have no video output connector, would still define an output of type destination that represents the manifestation of the video on the screen.

Parameters
Name Details
routes

Set routing sources for the given destination nodes.

The keys of this dictionary are the destination nodes. The values specify the source(s) for audio and video.

Not all device will support breakaway (different audio and video sources, or only one of those). In such cases, the driver would route both audio and video, and if multiple sources were specified, prefer the video source.

For devices which support clearing routes, the route may be cleared by routing null for audio and/or video. If the entire ActiveRoute value itself is null, it is treated as clearing both the audio and video (if applicable). If clearing routes is not supported by the device, the destination node will indicate that it is permanently active.

Outputs not listed in this parameter are unaffected.

typeDef 

    type: object

    itemTypeRef: ActiveRoute
Example
Copy 
[EntityCommand(Id = "mediaDevice:route")]
    public void MediaDeviceRoute(IDictionary<string, MediaDeviceActiveRoute> routes)
    {
        // TODO Your code here
    }

Properties

nodes

Fully Qualified Id: mediaDevice:nodes

Lists the media nodes on the device, including those representing physical connectors, logical connectors, media services, audio mixer channels and devices such as microphones, cameras, speakers and displays.

The keys of this dictionary are the IDs of the nodes. Other properties provide context and reference IDs from this collection. This property serves as a central index for definitions of these nodes which may be referenced in multiple other properties. Applications will normally only reference this property to access additional information about a node that was pointed to by another property. See the connectors, availableRoutes, and audioMixer:nodes for additional information.

The entity property of these nodes may implement the mediaContentContext capability and provide additional hints on how the node is used.

typeDef 

    type: object

    itemTypeRef: mediaDevice:Node

Example

    }
connectors

Fully Qualified Id: mediaDevice:connectors

Lists the physical and logical connectors on the device

The keys of this dictionary are the IDs of the connectors. This dictionary includes both inputs and outputs. The sources and destinations will indicate their association with these connectors.

This property should be populated by the driver as early as possible, ideally before it reports that it has finished configuration. That way, an installer can configure routing even when the device is is offline. That said, there may be cases where things like media services, expander cards, and streams are not known until the driver can connect to the device and retrieve its information.

While unusual, the list of connectors can change during operation due to device firmware updates, licensing, or hardware configuration changes. However, any changes typically require user intervention on the application side to reconfigure routes manually (unless the connectors are unused).

Drivers should expect that some applications may not handle changes to this dictionary gracefully and be tolerant of the application attempting to take actions based upon its initial value (at a minimum, it should not cause the driver to crash). If changing this dictionary is necessary, drivers should use unique keys that will not collide with previously used or future connectors of different types. For example, a card slot could use "ex_hdmi_out_1" and then replace it with "ex_analog_1" after a swap to an analog card instead of a generic "ex_out_1" so that the application does not think it is the same connector and then use it incorrectly.

typeDef 

    type: object

    itemTypeRef: mediaDevice:Connector

Example
Copy 
[EntityProperty(Id = "mediaDevice:connectors")]
    public IDictionary<string, MediaDeviceConnector> MediaDeviceConnectors { get; set; }
    
    private void TriggerMediaDeviceConnectorsChangedEvent()
    {
        NotifyPropertyChanged("mediaDevice:connectors", CreateValueForEntries(MediaDeviceConnectors));
    }
availableRoutes

Fully Qualified Id: mediaDevice:availableRoutes

Lists media nodes on the device which support having other nodes routed to them

The keys of this dictionary are the IDs of the nodes and match keys in the nodes dictionary.

In order to support devices with layered routing schemes or that may route to a node which feeds into a mix channel or another capability, this API does not specifically distinguish device inputs and outputs. Each node will describe which other nodes can be routed to it. The application can choose to present this as a flat list while still supporting arbitrarily complex devices, or render a sophisticated routing network which visualizes the relationships.

The application can still find "pure sources" by looking for nodes which can be routed to other ones but are not level keys in the availableRoutes (and thus cannot have anything routed to them). A "pure destination" will be a key in this dictionary and will not be listed as a routable source by other members of this dictionary.

The connectors can be checked to see which of the routing nodes come from external connections (as opposed to media sources or destinations).

The "final destination" of a media route (video display, speakers, etc.) will usually implement the mediaContentContext capability and denote which contexts it is most applicable to. Source nodes will often do the same.

typeDef 

    type: object

    itemTypeRef: mediaDevice:AvailableRoute

Example
Copy 
[EntityProperty(Id = "mediaDevice:availableRoutes")]
    public IDictionary<string, MediaDeviceAvailableRoute> MediaDeviceAvailableRoutes { get; set; }
    
    private void TriggerMediaDeviceAvailableRoutesChangedEvent()
    {
        NotifyPropertyChanged("mediaDevice:availableRoutes", CreateValueForEntries(MediaDeviceAvailableRoutes));
    }
activeRoutes

Fully Qualified Id: mediaDevice:activeRoutes

Lists the currently active routes (audio, video, or both)

Not all devices will support route feedback, so this property will sometimes not be implemented.

Any "permanent" routes (outputs that are permanently active and have only one possible input or input bus) should be included in this list when the driver supports feedback. When the driver does not support feedback, it should not implement this property. The application will need to identify the permanent routes by looking at the properties of the availableRoutes.

If the device implements devicePower, the application must also consider its power state in determining whether routes are active or not. Similarly, if the input, output, or source as an associated entity which implements devicePower, that state must also be factored into the application's decision making. The driver is not required to clear the activeRoutes when powered off if the route will automatically resume once powered on again.

typeDef 

    type: object

    itemTypeRef: ActiveRoute

Example

    }

Fully Qualified Id: mediaSignal:isVideoPresent

Indicates if a video device (or video component of an A/V device) is physically connected or paired.

An AV signal that knows "media present" but cannot tell if video is present should mirror "media present" to isAudioPresent and isVideoPresent. That way an application checking specifically for one or the other will get the best answer it can without having to check a separate "media present" property.

isAudioActive

Fully Qualified Id: mediaSignal:isAudioActive

Indicates if audio is present active on the audio signal.

The audio level required to be considered "active" is device dependent. The device driver should only implement this property if the device provides unsolicited feedback for this state. The driver should not attempt to poll for the active state of a device or interpret an incoming "level" to determine the active state. Because this property may cause frequent change events, it can be enabled/disabled via enableIsAudioActive/enableIsAudioActive/isAudioActiveEnabled.

The amount of kilobits being streamed per second.

Fully Qualified Id: mediaStream:encoders

A dictionary of all broadcasting streams pertaining to the entity keyed with the associated mediaDevice:Connector's ID with values of the stream info Encoder object.

If a single signal is available with different aspects (bit rate, resolution, etc...), each available option must be represented by a distinct Info referencing a distinct mediaDevice:Connector which then references a common mediaDevice:Node.

Movement

panTilt

Enables control over pan and tilt movement as well as the corresponding artificial bounds.

Commands

left

Fully Qualified Id: panTilt:left

Pans the device left. This command controls the orientation of the device in the z-rotational axis. This command is mutually exclusive with other panTilt movement commands.

If this command is executed while another command is already running, the new command's behavior must overwrite the old behavior.

setOrientation

Fully Qualified Id: panTilt:setOrientation

Directly sets the panAngle and tiltAngle of the device.

One or both of setOrientation.pan and setOrientation.tilt are required.

When selecting a value that wraps around the range on an unbounded device with endless pan, the driver must choose the shortest path between the given orientations.

For example, panAngle is 120deg and the new setOrientation.pan is -120deg, the device must pan right from 120deg through -180deg to 180deg and then to -120deg since the distance is 120deg panning right from 120deg but 240deg panning left from 120deg.

Parameters
Name Details
panAngle

The pan angle. Attempting to set to a value outside the bounds will result in the device being set to the closest bound.

typeDef 

    type: number

    range 

        minimum: -180

        maximum: 180

    units: Degrees

optionalFeature: True

optionalParameter: True

Properties

panAngle

Fully Qualified Id: panTilt:panAngle

The angle along the pannable range of the device. Negative numbers represent a left pan and positive numbers represent a right pan relative to the device's origin position.

If the leftBound is less than the rightBound then the panAngle must be greater than or equal to the leftBound AND less than or equal to the rightBound. If the leftBound is greater than the rightBound then this value must be greater than or equal to the leftBound OR less than or equal to the rightBound.

The value of this property must be in the range (-180, 180]. Any values associated with this property may be set to -180 which must be completely analogous to using 180.

typeDef 

    type: number

    range 

        minimum: -180

        maximum: 180

    units: Degrees

Units: Degrees
Example
Copy
[EntityProperty(
        Id = "panTilt:panAngle",
        Units = "Degrees"
    )]
    public double PanTiltPanAngle { get; set; }
    
    private void TriggerPanTiltPanAngleChangedEvent()
    {
        NotifyPropertyChanged("panTilt:panAngle", new DriverEntityValue(PanTiltPanAngle));
    }
tiltAngle

Fully Qualified Id: panTilt:tiltAngle

The angle along the tiltable range of the device. Negative numbers represent a downwards tilt while a positive number represents an upward tilt.

This value must be less than or equal to the topBound and greater than or equal the bottomBound.

The value of this property must be in the range (-180, 180]. Any values associated with this property may be set to -180 which must be completely analogous to using 180.

typeDef 

    type: number

    range 

        minimum: -180

        maximum: 180

    units: Degrees

leftBound

Fully Qualified Id: panTilt:leftBound

The leftmost pannable angle, whether by mechanical design or software imposed.

This value may be less than or greater than rightBound and restrict panAngle based on the following rules.

If the leftBound is less than the rightBound then the panAngle must be greater than or equal to the leftBound AND less than or equal to the rightBound. If the leftBound is greater than the rightBound then this value must be greater than or equal to the leftBound OR less than or equal to the rightBound.

typeDef 

    type: number

        maximum: 180

    units: Degrees

Platform

platform

Describes a device which contains other independent child devices, like a gateway bridge to another ecosystem of devices.

The devices contained by this capability may require configuration before they are usable.

Types

ManagedDevice

Fully Qualified Id: platform:ManagedDevice

Describes a child device that may appear in the managedDevices collection.

Properties
Name Details
name

Name associated with the device, usually set by the user via the device's interface when it was paired to the platform device.

This name may change, so the "id" should be used to identify the device.

For device whose API does not support a name, drivers must still report some user-identiable string for the name.

Type: string
manufacturer

The manufacturer of this device

Type: string
model

The device model name

Type: string
serialNumber

The device's serial number, if available

Will be null if the device's API does not report out the serial number.

Type: string
uxCategory

The User Experience category for the device

This describes the type of device that this is. It should ONLY be used for categorization purposes for selecting an icon or helping organize the device into a list. It should NOT be used to determine how to use the device.

In practice, devices can fit into multiple of these categories. The driver developer may have to choose what they consider the closest, or use "other" if no other categories apply. Applications should inspect the definition of the device instance to determine its capabilities and assume nothing about the device based on this string.

Type: DeviceUxCategory
briefDescription

Details of the device not covered by other properties on this object. This is intended to be shown in a user interface to help users identify key details about a device before interacting with it.

May be null. Drivers should only populate this description if there is a meaningful value to list here. Do not add redundant descriptions that simply duplicate information already contained in this object.

Type: string
Constructor and Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "platform:ManagedDevice")]
    public class PlatformManagedDevice
    {
        public PlatformManagedDevice(
            string name,
            string manufacturer,
            string model,
            string serialNumber,
            DeviceUxCategory uxCategory,
            string briefDescription
        )
        {
            Name = name;
            Manufacturer = manufacturer;
            Model = model;
            SerialNumber = serialNumber;
            UxCategory = uxCategory;
            BriefDescription = briefDescription;
        }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public string Name { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public string Manufacturer { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public string Model { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public string SerialNumber { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public DeviceUxCategory UxCategory { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public string BriefDescription { get; }
    }

Commands

refreshDevices

Fully Qualified Id: platform:refreshDevices

Tells the device to refresh its collection of children.

The collection of children may change even if this is not called. However, applications must call this method when they expect it to change. It may be expensive to refresh the collection, so drivers may choose to only refresh when this is called.

Example
Copy 
[EntityCommand(Id = "platform:refreshDevices")]
    public void PlatformRefreshDevices()
    {
        // TODO Your code here
    }

Properties

managedDevices

Fully Qualified Id: platform:managedDevices

Dictionary of known child devices and their associated metadata

Keys are the controller ID for the device, unique across the entire driver (but not multiple instances of the same driver).

If the root device is a platform device, and it has child devices which themselves have children, all controller IDs must still be unique across all the levels.

This ID must persist across restarts of the driver such that the application can remember the ID and find the same child device again.

Note that child devices may themselves have configuration items that must be applied in order to access them. When accessing a child device for the first time after the driver is loaded, the application should check the device's status to see if it requires configuration, and if so, configure it. Alternatively, if it previously acquired configuration settings and knows the device requires configuration, and knows it has not already done so, it may immediately apply the configuration. In such a case, the application should still wait for the child device's ID to appear in the collection of devices beneath the parent (as opposed to immediately trying to do this after configuring the parent) as the driver may not yet have gathered the collection of children from the device.

If creating the child device is expensive, the driver developer may choose to lazy-load the child device by waiting until it is accessed by the application to create it. This is important for the application to consider as it must at least check if the device is configured, configure it, or get its initial state. It should already do that anyway, but until it does, it may not receive any value updates or events from that device since the driver may be lazy-loading it.

typeDef 

    type: deviceDictionary

    itemTypeRef: ManagedDevice

Example
Copy

        Id = "platform:managedDevices",
        Type = DriverEntityValueType.DeviceDictionary,

    )]

Power

deviceAutoPowerOff

This capability describes a feature which automatically powers off a device after a period of time

In the context of this capability, "off" refers to the power state as defined by devicePower. If that power state does not apply to the aspect of the device being automatically turned off, do not use this capability. For example, a feature which turns lights off after a period of time would need a different capability.
