devicePower

This capability describes the overall power state of a device which needs to be powered on before it can be controlled

This is intended to control power on a device but not start its operation. For example, it can be used to turn on a washing machine so that it can later be started in a specific separate API call.

This does NOT apply to actions like turning a light on or powering a bank on a power controller or turning on a fan. Those actions should use their own specific API. This capability is solely intended to be used to power on a device so that it may be controlled, not to cause the device to perform an action.

When a device or entity implements this capability, the application must use it to power on that device before attempting to control it.

While not limited to media devices, this capability is commonly implemented on them. A media device with no permanently active outputs fits the above descriptions perfectly. However, it is worth noting that many devices do have permanently active outputs, and powering on those outputs is likely to start that device's primary function (such as turning on a display). However, in the context of media, a display is a controllable media destination, not a separate "device" per-se. The API only cares that the media destination is powered on, not that it is a display specifically. That, in addition to the fact that displays do not typically support discrete power control over their internal processor and the display screen itself and thus a separate power property and command would be redundant, is the justification for media devices appearing to "break the rule" for the use of devicePower.

Types

State

Fully Qualified Id: devicePower:State

Describes the power states a device can be in

Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "devicePower:State")]
    public enum DevicePowerState
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// Indicates that the device is powered off and cannot be controlled until <see
        /// cref="On"/> is sent.
        /// While in this state, the application should not send any commands except <see
        /// cref="On"/>. Other commands may be ineffective or even discarded if the driver must
        /// avoid sending them due to device workarounds. However, the driver should expect to
        /// receive them and handle them without causing errors.
        /// </summary>
        Off,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Indicates that the device is presently transitioning to the "on" state
        /// While in this state, certain operations may be unavailable or queued until the
        /// device is ready in the "on" state. Drivers must queue operations which set states
        /// (e.g. routing commands) and execute them once the device is on. Other operations
        /// (such as press and hold APIs) should not advance more than a single step or queue
        /// more than a single command until the state is "on".
        /// </summary>
        PoweringOn,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Indicates that the device is powered on and ready for control
        /// This is the only power state where all commands are valid and can be sent to the
        /// device.
        /// </summary>
        On,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// Indicates that the device is presently transitioning to the "off" state
        /// While in this state, the application should not send any commands except <see
        /// cref="On"/>. If <see cref="On"/> is executed, it will be queued until the power-off
        /// process completes. Other commands may be ineffective or even discarded if the driver
        /// must avoid sending them due to device workarounds. However, the driver should expect
        /// to receive them and handle them without causing errors.
        /// </summary>
        PoweringOff,
    }

Commands

on

Fully Qualified Id: devicePower:on

Turns the device on

If the device is in the middle of powering off or in the waiting period after power-off, the driver must queue this operation and complete it when possible. While it must not update the state to "poweringOn" until the power-on message is actually sent to the device, it should treat incoming commands as if it were in the "poweringOn" state. For example, subsequent routing commands should also be queued and executed once on.

If a queued off command exists, this will cancel and replace that command. The driver should always attempt to send this command when instructed, even if it thinks the device is already on unless it does not make sense for the particular device.

Example
Copy 
[EntityCommand(Id = "devicePower:on")]
    public void DevicePowerOn()
    {
        // TODO Your code here
    }
off

Fully Qualified Id: devicePower:off

Turns the device off

If the device is in the middle of powering on or in the waiting period after sending a power-on command, the driver must queue this operation and complete it when possible.

While it must not update the state to "powering off" until the power-off message is actually sent to the device, it should treat incoming commands as if it were in the "powering off" state (i.e. ignore anything that comes before "power on" and can't be sent while off).

When this command is received, the driver should discard any pending operations that it cannot perform while off and prioritize the off command.

Example
Copy 
[EntityCommand(Id = "devicePower:off")]
    public void DevicePowerOff()
    {
        // TODO Your code here
    }
toggle

Fully Qualified Id: devicePower:toggle

Toggles the power state of the device.

The same logic for on and off applies when using toggle so discrete on and off commands are generally more preferable to use.

This command is primarily defined so that button and/or sequence programming can reference it. It may optionally be implemented by the driver, but toggling is usually best managed by the application so that its business logic remains aware of the desired power state of the device.

A toggle-only device implementing devicePower is of limited use since devicePower is intended to power a device so that it may be controlled, not as a feature control item itself.

    }
setReadyTimeAfterPowerOn

Fully Qualified Id: devicePower:setReadyTimeAfterPowerOn

Sets the device's readyTimeAfterPowerOn in milliseconds.

When the driver uses a predetermined timer to determine how long to wait in the "poweringOn" state before being fully on and able to send commands, this overrides the time that the driver uses.

Drivers typically use conservative times for compatibility with the worst-case timing on the slowest supported model. This API exists so the installer can tune the timing to match the performance of the device they have.

Properties

state

Fully Qualified Id: devicePower:state

Reports the power state of the device

This must be "on" in order to be able control the device, with the exception that the on command may be issued while this state is "off".

Note that this may update due to device feedback, including transitions from "on" to "powering off". The driver will typically apply its ready times in response to feedback when the device can give that power feedback before being ready in cases where the device cannot respond to commands for a period of time, even after power feedback is available.

See the documentation for State for details.

This is a high-level state property that informs the application about when it can and cannot control the device due to power state changes. It is not intended to model detailed power state information, such as delineating "standby" and "low power" modes from "off".

typeRef: State

    }
readyTimeAfterPowerOn

Fully Qualified Id: devicePower:readyTimeAfterPowerOn

Reports the current setting for the ready time after power-on in milliseconds

When the driver uses a predetermined timer to determine how long to wait in the "poweringOn" state before being fully on and able to send other commands, this reports the time that the driver uses.

When the driver dynamically determines the device's readiness after power-on, this property reports the driver developer's best estimate of what that time will typically be.

Note that it is preferable to wait for state rather than to mirror this timer in the application, since the driver may be able to detect when the device is ready and shorten that time. Additionally, if the device is running slower than usual, this time may be too short.

This was previously referred to as "warmup time" with Crestron media devices and serves the same purpose, but with a name that is more broadly applicable.

    type: integer

    units: Milliseconds

    range 

        minimum: 0

Scenes

sceneController

Capability to be implemented by a device which supports "scenes" which may apply to this device or to multiple sub-devices.

More than one scene may be active at a given time as some scenes may contain other scenes, and other scenes might not overlap.

This capability contains two implementations of scenes. Named scenes use the scenes property and are tracked by the device or driver. Open-ended scenes use the numberedScenes property and are only used as identifiers for accompanying commands.

Types

Scene

Fully Qualified Id: sceneController:Scene

Describes a scene on a device

Properties
Name Details
name

The user-friendly name for this scenes.

Type: string
supportsIsActive

True if the scene supports "is active" feedback

If false, the value of isActive must be ignored.

This property will typically not change values. However, it might when the scene is edited, depending on the device and its API.

Type: bool
isActive

True if the scene is active

Value is not applicable when supportsIsActive is false.

The scene could be active either because it was previously recalled, or because the device otherwise reached the state associated with the scene. Not all devices will support detecting the latter case, so some devices will only report true when recallScene was called.

When the device only reports the last-recalled scene and does not provide a way to know if the device has since changed from those values via other means, the driver developer must either set isActive to false when it gets feedback or an API call that could potentially de-activate the scene, or choose to set supportsIsActive to false.

Type: bool
isToggle

True if calling recallScene while active will de-activate the scene

Common with things like lighting scenes where activating the scene while already active will turn the affected lights off.

This property will typically not change values. However, it might when the scene is edited, depending on the device and its API.

Type: bool
applicableSceneTypes

Types that apply to this scene

This can be used by the application to help group scenes. For example, if the application wants to list out lighting scenes in a menu, it can look for scenes with applicableSceneTypes containing "light". That way, it does not pick up media-related scenes or other unrelated items.

When null, this should be treated as if the only category was "unknown". When empty, it means the scene is empty and affects nothing.

Type: ICollection<SceneControllerSceneType>
Constructor and Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "sceneController:Scene")]
    public class SceneControllerScene
    {
        public SceneControllerScene(
            string name,
            bool supportsIsActive,
            bool isActive,
            bool isToggle,
            ICollection<SceneControllerSceneType> applicableSceneTypes
        )
        {
            Name = name;
            SupportsIsActive = supportsIsActive;
            IsActive = isActive;
            IsToggle = isToggle;
            ApplicableSceneTypes = applicableSceneTypes;
        }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public string Name { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public bool SupportsIsActive { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public bool IsActive { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public bool IsToggle { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public ICollection<SceneControllerSceneType> ApplicableSceneTypes { get; }
    }

SceneType

Fully Qualified Id: sceneController:SceneType

Describes predefined types of scenes for categorization purposes

A scene may include multiple types when it affects a set of devices that fit into multiple categories.

Applications may use this property to find scenes that affect the area they are interested, or to determine if a scene may have "side-effects" from the perspective of their use case (i.e. a lighting scene the application wants to show on a lighting page but warn the user that it also affects media).

Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "sceneController:SceneType")]
    public enum SceneControllerSceneType
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// Is is unknown what is affected by this scene.
        /// When listed in combination with other scene categories, it means that the scene is
        /// known to affect those other categories, but it is unknown whether it affects
        /// anything else.
        /// </summary>
        Unknown,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The scene is known to affect a device state which did not fit into any of the
        /// predefined categories.
        /// </summary>
        Other,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The scene affects lighting devices.
        /// </summary>
        Light,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The scene affects video capture devices, such as a camera.
        /// </summary>
        Camera,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The scene affects audio devices, such as a speaker or TV.
        /// Commonly used in combination with "video" for multimedia devices.
        /// </summary>
        Audio,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The scene affects video display devices, such as a projector or TV.
        /// Commonly used in combination with "audio" for multimedia devices.
        /// </summary>
        Video,
    }

numberedScenesApplicableTypes

Fully Qualified Id: sceneController:numberedScenesApplicableTypes

Types that apply to numbered scenes

This can be used by the application to help group scenes. For example, if the application wants to list out lighting scenes in a menu, it can list the numberedScenes if this property contains "light". That way, it does not pick up media-related scenes or other unrelated items.

When null, this should be treated as if the only category was "unknown". When empty, it means that open-ended scenes are not supported.

typeDef 

    type: array

    itemTypeRef: SceneType

Status

errorIndicator

Capability to be implemented by a device which supports reporting errors

Types

DeviceErrorCode

Fully Qualified Id: errorIndicator:DeviceErrorCode

Defines a device error code

These are unique per device only. Comparing error codes from different devices may yield incorrect results.

These specific error codes may be consumed by a user interface that is aware of a specific device model and its types of errors.

Properties
Name Details
code

Error code identifying the error that occurred

This is contextual to the manufacturer and/or the device model that raised the error. The manufacturer's documentation may be needed to decipher this error.

NOTE: This is a string because some manufacturers may use alphanumeric error codes.

Type: string
message

Error message describing the error code

Typically this string will be in English so that Crestron can diagnose and debug the error, but depending on the driver's author or device's language, it may be in their native language.

Type: string
severity

Indicates the severity of the error

Type: ErrorIndicatorDeviceErrorCodeSeverity
Constructor and Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "errorIndicator:DeviceErrorCode")]
    public class ErrorIndicatorDeviceErrorCode
    {
        public ErrorIndicatorDeviceErrorCode(
            string code,
            string message,
            ErrorIndicatorDeviceErrorCodeSeverity severity
        )
        {
            Code = code;
            Message = message;
            Severity = severity;
        }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public string Code { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public string Message { get; }
    
        [EntityProperty]
        public ErrorIndicatorDeviceErrorCodeSeverity Severity { get; }
    }
DeviceErrorCodeSeverity

Fully Qualified Id: errorIndicator:DeviceErrorCodeSeverity

The severity level of an error

Definition
Copy 
[EntityDataType(Id = "errorIndicator:DeviceErrorCodeSeverity")]
    public enum ErrorIndicatorDeviceErrorCodeSeverity
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// The severity level is unknown
        /// </summary>
        Unknown,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The error has a high severity, usually indicating that some important function of
        /// the device is unavailable.
        /// </summary>
        Error,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The error has a low severity, usually indicating that some important function of the
        /// device is impaired, or a secondary function is unavailable.
        /// </summary>
        Warning,
    
        /// <summary>
        /// The error is informational-only and does not significantly impact device
        /// functionality.
        /// </summary>
        Info,
    }

Properties

errorCodes

Fully Qualified Id: errorIndicator:errorCodes

List of currently active error codes from the device and its manufacturer.

May be null or empty if no errors have occurred.

Note: This property is available even when readyIndicator:isReady is false. When readyIndicator:isReady is false and this is non-empty, the errors describe what is preventing the device from becoming ready.

    itemTypeRef: DeviceErrorCode

onlineIndicator

Capability to be implemented by a device which has the potential to be "offline"

Most physical devices will need to implement this capability.

Refer to the readyIndicator capability for additional information about scenarios where the device's capabilities are not yet available for use.

Properties

isOnline

Fully Qualified Id: onlineIndicator:isOnline

Indicates if the device is online and ready for communication.

Unless otherwise noted on a specific capability, all commands, properties, and events appearing on device capabilities are not available for use until this property is true.

typeDef 

    type: boolean

Example
Copy

    {
        NotifyPropertyChanged("onlineIndicator:isOnline", new DriverEntityValue(OnlineIndicatorIsOnline));
    }

readyIndicator

Capability to be implemented by a device which indicates when it is "ready" to accept commands. This is not necessarily the same as an "online" flag. The device may be online, but not "ready" yet.

Properties

isReady

Fully Qualified Id: readyIndicator:isReady

True when the device is ready to receive commands and return current information via any properties or commands with return values, as well as raise (feedback) events (if supported).

When this is false, it typically means the device is either offline or just not ready to communicate yet (i.e. online, but still loading).

Unless otherwise noted in a specific device capability property, command or event, all interactions with the device will not be available or valid until this property turns true.

Methods and properties may still be called while this property is false, however their values will be deemed unreliable (and will be set to either their last value or the default value) until this property changes to true.

If an error can occur that will prevent the device from ever being ready, the errorIndicator capability should be implemented in order to raise the error.

The device may also become ready, but have its errorIndicator:errorCodes property already set. This means the device is functional, but has errors that may prevent it from functioning properly.

All other errors will be raised after the device is ready. If the device stays ready, it means the device is functional, but has errors that may prevent it from functioning properly. If the device changes to not ready, it means the error is causing the device to be non-functional.

typeDef 

    type: boolean

Example
Copy 
[EntityProperty(Id = "readyIndicator:isReady")]
    public bool ReadyIndicatorIsReady { get; set; }
    
    private void TriggerReadyIndicatorIsReadyChangedEvent()
    {
        NotifyPropertyChanged("readyIndicator:isReady", new DriverEntityValue(ReadyIndicatorIsReady));
    }

User Interface

indicatorLight

This capability describes the basic functions of an indicator light component of a device, such as the LED on a microphone.

This is not intended to comprehend more complicated user interface devices like programmable keypads.

Fully Qualified Id: indicatorLight:setIntensity

Sets the intensity/brightness of the indicator light.

It is device dependent if this command will turn the light on when off. Since intensity may conflict with colorRgb, a driver shall not implement both setIntensity and setColorRgb.
